questions.q: Which of the following fractures is most commonly associated with osteoporosis?
questions.explanation: Colles fracture (distal radius fracture) is commonly seen in osteoporotic patients after falls on outstretched hands

questions.q: What is the most common complication of total hip replacement?
questions.explanation: Deep vein thrombosis is the most common complication following total hip replacement surgery

questions.q: What is the most common complication after total knee replacement?
questions.explanation: DVT is the most common complication following total knee arthroplasty

questions.q: Which physical finding is most specific for ACL tear?
questions.explanation: The Lachman test has the highest specificity for ACL tears

questions.q: What type of hernia presentation predispose to strangulation
questions.explanation: Irreducible hernia predispose to strangulation and also can be diagnostic of omentocele

questions.q: The following are clinical presentations of hernia
questions.explanation: Hernias are extremely tender

questions.q: Risk factors of hernia Include
questions.explanation: Chronic cough, pregnancy, congenital, pregnancy and weight lifting are all risk factors of hernia not cough

questions.q: The following are compositions of hernia
questions.explanation: The components of hernia are the sac, the coverings and the contents

questions.q: Which one is incorrect regarding hernia
questions.A: Strangulated hernia occurs when the blood supply of its content is severely impaired
questions.B: Both direct and indirect hernia are considered to originate from a congenital variant
questions.C: There is an interference of blood supply in obstructed hernia
questions.D: Irreducible hernia is diagnostic of omentocele
questions.explanation: Obstructed hernia is an irreducible hernia containing bowels but there is no interference to the blood supply of the bowel. It culminates in strangulation

questions.q: What type of hernia passes through the inguinal canal and is lateral to the inferior epigastric artery
questions.explanation: Indirect inguinal hernia passes through the inguinal canal and is lateral to the inferior epigastric artery while direct inguinal hernia passes through the hesselbach’s triangle and is medial to inferior epigastric artery

questions.q: The following are complications of herniotomy
questions.explanation: Injury to ilioinguinal nerve, post operative hydrocele, injury to vas deferens, iatrogenic undescended testis and post operational urinary retention are all complications of herniotomy

questions.q: The following are clinical features of appendicitis
questions.C: Right iliac fossa localized peritonitis (may become generalized)
questions.explanation: There is an increase pain on movement with appendicitis

questions.q: The following are signs seen in appendicitis
questions.explanation: Kernigs sign is present in meningitis. Rovsing’s sign, psoas sign and obturator sign are all present in appendicitis

questions.q: Which is not a complication of appendicitis
questions.explanation: Appendiceal abscess, perforation, spreading peritonitis, appendiceal gangrene, appendiceal mass and perforation are all complications of appendicitis

questions.q: One of the following is not an immediate post op complications of appendectomy
questions.explanation: Bleeding, perforation, and abscess are all immediate complications of appendectomy. Adhesion, and occlusion to fallopian tubes leading to infertility are long term complications

questions.q: The peak incidence age for appendicitis
questions.explanation: The peak incidence age for appendicitis is 10-20 years

questions.q: Which of the following is not an intramural cause of obstructive jaundice
questions.B: Parasitic infections such as ascaris lumbricoides and schistosoma japonicum
questions.explanation: Parasitic infections are causes of intraluminal obstructive jaundice not intramural obstructive jaundice

questions.q: All are clinical features of obstructive jaundice
questions.explanation: Pale stool, jaundice, itching, poor wound healing and bleeding are all features of obstructive jaundice

questions.q: Pre operative measures in jaundice patients include
questions.B: Give IM vit. K 10 mg or fresh frozen plasma
questions.explanation: Hydration, nutritional support, antibiotics, prevent hypoglycemia, correct anemia, vit. K, and give oral cholestyramine are all pre op prep for surgery in jaundice patients.

questions.q: Definite treatment of common bile duct stones
questions.explanation: Surgery (cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration)

questions.q: Principles for the management of patients with obstructive jaundice
questions.C: Rx problems peculiar to jaundice patients
questions.explanation: Resuscitation, investigation, Rx problems peculiar to jaundice patients, provide a channel for draining the biliary tract and treat the underlying cause if possible are the principles of management of obstructive jaundice

questions.q: The second most common cause of cancer death in the west
All are risk factors of colon cancer
questions.explanation: Asbestosis is s risk factor of lung cancer not colorectal cancer. Dietary pattern (increase in animal fat consumption), cigarette smoking, alcoholism, family history of colorectal cancer or any other cancer are all risk factors of developing colorectal cancer

questions.q: The following are clinical presentations of colorectal cancer
What is the peak age for developing colorectal cancer
questions.explanation: The peak incidence for developing colorectal cancer is in 60-70 year olds, both men and women

questions.q: The following are observed on examination of patient with colorectal cancer
Which is the tumor marker of colorectal cancer
questions.explanation: Carcinoembryonic antigen is the marker of colorectal cancer, use in monitoring of recurrence and progress. CA 125 is a marker of ovarian cancer, CA 19-9 is a marker of pancreatic cancer and PSA is a marker of prostate cancer

questions.q: Kearns-Sayre syndrome and Leber hereditary optic neuropathy are noted in both males and females but are inherited only through the mother. These conditions are examples of:
Tay-Sachs disease is best described as:
FISH in genetic testing is best described as:
questions.B: An enzyme assay to detect mutations
questions.D: A test to identify the chromosomal location of an affected gene

questions.q: The polymerase chain reaction is best described as:
questions.A: A method to produce many antigenic epitopes
questions.B: A method to amplify small quantities of DNA or RNA

questions.q: Trinucleotide repeats are implicated in the etiology of all of the following except:

A 1-yr-old presents with a disease that is classically an autosomal recessive trait (such as cystic fibrosis). The father is tested and, with 99% confidence, he is demonstrated to be negative for the carrier state. The most likely explanation is:
questions.A: Mutation to an autosomal dominant trait
questions.B: Uniparental isodisomy transmission from the mother
questions.C: Uniparental isodisomy transmission from the father
questions.D: Imprinting of the missing recessive gene
